description: From Middle English bold, from Old English bold, blod, bolt, botl (“house, dwelling-place, mansion, hall, castle, temple”), from Proto-Germanic *budlą, *buþlą (“house, dwelling”), from Proto-Indo-European *bʰew- (“to grow, wax, swell”) or *bʰuH-.

Cognate with Old Frisian bold (“house”) (whence North Frisian bol, boel, bøl (“house”)), North Frisian bodel, budel (“property, inheritance”), Middle Low German būdel (“property, real estate”). Related to build.

From Middle English bold, bolde, bald, beald, from Old English bald, beald (“bold, brave, confident, strong, of good courage, presumptuous, impudent”), from Proto-West Germanic *balþ, from Proto-Germanic *balþaz (“strong, bold”), from Proto-Indo-European *bʰel-, *bʰlē- (“to bloat, swell, bubble”).

Cognate with Dutch boud (“bold, courageous, fearless”), Middle High German balt (“bold”) (whence German bald (“soon”)), Swedish båld (“bold, dauntless”). Perhaps related to Albanian ballë (“forehead”) and Old Prussian balo (“forehead”). For semantic development compare Italian affrontare (“to face, to deal with”), sfrontato (“bold, daring, insolent”), both from Latin frons (“forehead”).

examples: Bold deeds win admiration and, sometimes, medals.
the painter's bold use of colour and outline

entries.meaning: (typography, of typefaces) Having thicker strokes than the ordinary form of the typeface.
examples: The last word of this sentence is bold.
[…]  even the boldeſt and moſt affirmative Philoſophy, which has ever attempted to impoſe its crude Dictates and Principles on Mankind.
All of her children are terribly bold and never do as they are told.

description: From Middle English bolden, balden, from Old English baldian, bealdian, from Proto-Germanic *balþōną, related to *balþaz (see above). Cognate with Old High German irbaldōn (“to become bold, dare”).

verbs.description: bold (third-person singular simple present bolds, present participle bolding, simple past and past participle bolded)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To make (a font or some text) bold.
(transitive, obsolete) To make bold or daring.
examples: It touches vs, as France inuades our landNot bolds the King, with others whome I feare,Moſt iuſt and heauy cauſes make oppoſe.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, obsolete) To become bold or brave.
